name: Transition Extreme
description: Transition Extreme Skatepark, or TX as it’s known by the locals, is Aberdeen’s very own plywood paradise, providing the North East with an unbeatable space for skateboarding, BMXing and inline skating. Built in 2007, the parks design was the brainchild of local skateboarding and skatepark builder Andy Dobson who, alongside Dave Partridge from Carve Skatepark Design and with the input of local skaters and BMXers has created a world class, challenging layout based on the flow of outdoor concrete parks.
address: Links Road, Aberdeen, Scotland, AB24 5NN

name: Peterhead Skatepark
description: Outdoor modular wooden skatepark. This park is currently in need of repair, it is useable but Blueskate Peterhead have started the process to redevelop the whole park and bring it up to date.
address: Meethill Road, Peterhead, Aberdeenshire, Scotland, AB42 2EF

name: Torry Skatepark
description: Outdoor concrete skatepark. Quarter pipe, wave ramp, box jump, a frame with down rail. Maybe take brush as stones from dirt track sometimes in park.
address: 120 Saint Fitticks Road, Torry, Scotland, AB11 8TP

name: Cove Skatepark
description: Simple outdoor concrete modular park with large flat bank and quarterpipe at either end. Middle section consists of a small spine attached to a fun-box with a step-up and a separate ledge approximately 6ft long.
address: Charleston School, Charleston Road, Cove Bay, Scotland, AB123FH

name: Kincorth Skatepark
description: Small but rad outdoor concrete park with a load of different features such as bowled spine, ledges, flatbanks and quarters.
address: 7 Kincorth Cir, Aberdeen, Scotland, AB12 5NL

name: Westburn Skatepark
description: This outdoor concrete park was originally built many years ago, but was revamped and a new modern extension added in 2018. The existing old section of the park had some refurbishment but the main work being the addition of a brand new 3 set, 4 set, curved quarter, euro gap, rails, funbox and ledges.
address: 26 Cornhill Road, Aberdeen, Scotland, AB25 2DF

name: Cults Skatepark
description: Outdoor concrete bowl with box / rollover in middle, long quarter pipe with bank at side.
address: Cairnlee Road, East Cults, Aberdeen, Scotland, AB15 9RG

name: Byron Skatepark
description: Outdoor concrete modular style park with a large mellow quarter / bank along the whole of one end and combination of banks, quarters and a roll in at the opposite end. The middle section consists of two spines at either side, a volcano and a small funbox with a ledge along one side.
address: Allan Douglas Park, Quarry Road, Northfield, Aberdeen, Scotland, AB16 5TA

name: Fraserburgh Skatepark
description: Outdoor skatepark consisting of pre-cast concrete ramps on a tarmac base with flat banks, quarter pipes and funboxes.
address: Maconochie Road, Fraserburgh, Aberdeenshire, Scotland, AB43 9TH

name: Banff Skatepark
description: Outdoor wooden modular skatepark. Rhino ramp park with a fun DIY ledge. 2 quarter pipes, ledge and a kicker but unfortunately cant get enough space to get speed up for it. Cross Bridge on A98 coming from Macduff. Past coop then turn onto Airlie Gardens. Use car park beside Deveronvale Football Club 56 Airlie Gardens for sat nav. Admission is free and it is open from Monday to Friday 9am to 9 pm, Saturday 9am to 1pm and Sunday 11am to 6pm.
address: Airlie Gardens, Banff, Aberdeenshire, Scotland, AB45 1AZ

name: Pitmedden Skatepark
description: Outdoor concrete park. Ok for a small local park but is not that skateable. Time would be better spent at other nearby skateparks at Tarves or Oldmeldrum.
address: Pitmedden Park, Tarves Road, Ellon, Pitmedden, Aberdeenshire, Scotland, AB41 7NY

name: Oldmeldrum Skatepark
description: A concrete park in Old Meldrum near Aberdeen. Big ramps for all, plus a rail and banked hubba for all those irrepressible street rats.
address: Meldrum Pleasure Park, Park Crescent, Oldmeldrum, Aberdeenshire, Scotland, AB51 0DH

name: Inverurie Skatepark
description: Outdoor basic modular ramps on a tarmac base consisting of quarterpipe, flatbank and funbox.
address: Kellands Park, 6 Broadford, Inverurie, Aberdeenshire, Scotland, AB51 3WG

name: Kemnay Skatepark
description: Outdoor concrete park designed by Aberdeen-legend Andy Dobson, various transitions ranging from 3ft to 7ft, walls and ledges. 5′ rectangular bowl, spine, quarterpipes, flatbanks, hubba ledges.
address: Bogbeth Road, Kemnay, Inverurie, Aberdeenshire, Scotland, AB51 5RJ

name: Insch Skatepark
description: This is an outdoor metal skatepark consisting of a halfpipe, quarterpipe and a funbox along with a portable grind rail. All obstacles are made of metal and definitely show their age, the halfpipe and quarterpipe's coping doesn't stick out and the funbox has no coping. The bank ramp and stairs/rail on of the funbox don't have much flat ground surrounding them to perform tricks and the funbox and quarterpipe aren't lined up properly. On sunny days, the halfpipe can get pretty hot, luckily there are trees surrounding the rest of the park and the quarter pipe. The skate park is part of Bennachie Leisure Centre, the centre has a cafe, gym, toilets, changing rooms.
address: Bennachie Leisure Centre, Largie Road, Insch, Aberdeenshire, Scotland, AB52 6LT

name: Alford Skatepark
description: Outdoor concrete approx 1.8m deep double-bowl with spine / teardrop / volcano.
address: Greystone Rd, Alford, Aberdeenshire, Scotland, AB33 8TY

name: Huntly Skatepark
description: Small outdoor modular wooden park consisting of a quarterpipe Rhino ramp and a ledge. Directions - from Castle Street follow signs for Huntly Castle. Past war memorial, through a very narrow archway continue along single track road past Huntly Castle. At junction take sharp left then car park. Skatepark in childrens park. Toilet at Nordic Ski Centre.
address: Huntly Castle Park, Huntly, Aberdeenshire, Scotland, AB54 4SH

name: Keith Skatepark
description: Outdoor metal skatepark which was originally built circa 2003 but the skatepark is actively maintained and has had various improvements made in the last few years with new and replacement ramps added. The skatepark layout contains various quarterpipes / flatbank / roll-in and driveway / funbox / spine combinations as well as a miniramp.
address: Cuthil Park, Chapel Street, Keith, Moray, Scotland, AB55 5SL

name: Buckie Skatepark
description: Outdoor concrete park, lots of transitions, quarters, hips, corners, teardrop spine, driveway with rails, pyramid hip.
address: South Pringle Street, Buckie, Moray, Scotland, AB56 1PZ

name: Elgin Skatepark
description: Outdoor concrete park lots of transitions, quarters, corners and also a bank and extensions.
address: Cooper Park, Lossie Wynd North, Elgin, Moray, Scotland, IV30 1QB

name: Nairn Skatepark
description: All concrete pre-cast skatepark featuring 5ft half pipe, 3 x 5ft quarter pipes, jump box, flat bank, hub and two rails.
address: Mill Road, Nairn, Highlands, Scotland, IV12 5EP

name: Hopeman Skatepark
description: Outdoor wooden Skatelite surfaced park with a few different sized ramps, quarterpipes, hips, driveway and some rails.
address: 22 School Road, Hopeman, Elgin, Moray, Scotland, IV30 5SP

name: Banchory Skatepark
description: Steel surfaced mini-ramp. Banchory Skatepark Group are at the early stages of getting a new skatepark built at the time of publishing (Sept 2017).
address: Bellfield Park, Dee Street, Banchory, Aberdeenshire, Scotland, AB31 5ST

name: Stonehaven Skatepark
description: The park features a 5 foot deep concrete bowl with good coping. 3 small ramps, one with two stairs, a block, a rail, three 5 foot drops, two other ramps, a flat part, two 2 foot drops and a 6 foot drop.
address: Queen Elizabeth Park, Beach Road, Stonehaven, Aberdeenshire, Scotland, AB39 2RD

name: Fort Angus Skatepark
description: Outdoor metal surfaced miniramp, driveway, quarterpipes and rail.
address: Playpark, Great Glen Way, Fort Augustus, Invernesshire, Scotland, PH32 4DQ

name: Raigmore Skatepark
description: Outdoor concrete park, lots of transition, bowls, hips, quarters, rollover.
address: Community park, Ashton Rd, Raigmore, Inverness, Invernesshire, Scotland, IV2 3UY

name: Inverness Skatepark
description: Located in the Bught Park the skate park is a major new leisure facility built at a cost of £455,000. One of the best in in Scotland, the park covers an area of 1200 square metres and has something for every level of rider. The skate park has more than 10 features. The huge bowl has three grindable surfaces and ends in nine foot pool bowl. The tail of the Nessie head is part of a 50 metre jump section, and a fully ride-able coloured ‘thistle’is part of the extensive street section.
address: Bught Park, Bught Road, Inverness, Inverness-shire, Scotland, IV3 5SP

name: Beauly Mini Ramp
description: Skatelite surfaced miniramp, 4ft with 5ft extension.
address: Croyard Road, Beauly, Invernesshire, Scotland, IV4 7DJ

name: Muir of Ord Skatepark
description: Indoor Skatepark has been built out of skatelight with floodlighting around the skate park. Park is made up of, One half pipe at 5FT high, a hip, a 2 long 5ft quarters, a flat bank, a 5ft spine, a funbox and ledge, a pyramid and ledge, a roll in and flat bank. Lots of platform space, 1 rail and  flat land space too. There are major plans to upgrade the Skate Park, design plans are progressing and funding is being sourced. Regular fundraising events and educational  workshops are taking place.
address: Tarradale Gardens, Muir of Ord, Ross-shire, Scotland, IV67SJ

name: Tain Skatepark
description: Small metal park with funbox and quarters.
address: Chapel Road, Tain, Invernesshire, Scotland, IV19 1JE

name: Wick Skatepark
description: Fairly basic concrete modular park.
address: Grizzly Park, Wellington Avenue, Wick, Caithness, Scotland, KW1 5JB

name: Kirkwall Skatepark
description: This is Scotland's second-most northerly skatepark! It was originally built in 2005 and is mostly a tarmac surfaced wide mellow banked area with a four sided pyramid funbox in the centre and some ledges / rails. An additional concrete teardrop / spine and curved ledge on top of one of the banks were added circa 2020. In early 2022 a new concrete jump box, quarterpipe extension and metal flatbar rail were added and the base of the pyramid funbox resurfaced to make it smoother. You're probably not going to take a trip to Orkney just to skate this but it's Scotland's 2nd most northerly park and it's great to see that it is regularly used and has had some new features added in recent years, it would definitely be worth checking out if you're on holiday in Orkney!
address: Pickaquoy Rd, Kirkwall, Highlands & Islands, Scotland, KW15 1BX

name: Lerwick Skatepark
description: The skatepark starts on one side with a flat bank and block on the back side of a raised level that has a small flat bank running up the long side. Leading down to the lower level is another flat bank that features a stair set, hubba, rail, euro gap and a manny pad. Following on from this is a large bowled edge that acts as a return ramp and inset to this is an open sided bowl that has an extension around one corner. This is a great local park and only skatepark on the island. Whether you skate street or transitions these is something for you here, the selection of obstacles is decent and the arrangement makes good use of the available space. If you are on the island get yourself down here and check it out.
address: Knab Rd, Lerwick, Shetland Isles, Scotland, ZE1 0AX

name: Stornoway Skatepark
description: Modular skatepark with steel framed skatelite surface. Roll-in, driveway, quarter pipe and flatbank.
address: Bayhead, Stornoway, Highlands & Islands, Scotland, HS1 2DX

name: Laurencekirk Skatepark
description: The park has some quarterpipes, flat banks and a box.
address: Garvock Road, Laurencekirk, Aberdeenshire, Scotland, AB30 1FJ

name: Montrose Skatepark
description: Outdoor modular concrete skatepark, flatbank at one end, funbox with various transition options, quarterpipe at the other end.
address: Traill Drive, Montrose, Angus, Scotland, DD10 8EL

name: Forfar Skatepark
description: Outdoor concrete park featuring a quarter pipe with 5 / 6 ft high sections, this leads in to a spine / jumpbox combination with hubba ledge down the middle, leading into a wide flatbank. There is also a freestanding ledge.
address: Craig O'Loch Road, Forfar, Angus, Scotland, DD8 1BZ

name: Arbroath Skatepark
description: Large outdoor concrete park with a street section as well as a bowl section.
address: Queen's Drive, Arbroath, Angus, Scotland, DD11 2PT

name: Carnoustie Skatepark
description: Carnoustie skatepark finished its redevelopment in May 2015. Originally being given little more than a few ledges and a disabled ramp to skate, the skatepark now contains a full street plaza including hip, ledges, down rail, hubba, euro gap, as well as numerous ramps. the park also includes a large L shaped bowl; consisting of a small four foot section with hip, a 6 foot clam shell on the corner, and an 8 foot deep end with concrete coping. Situated right on the beach front it can get windy, but the park is right beside the main train station with regular arrivals from Glasgow Queen Street and Aberdeen station, there is a leisure centre next to the park with public toilets, a cafe, and a coop. A small walk up the road takes you to the high street with many more shops and food options.
address: Links Parade, Carnoustie, Angus, Scotland, DD7 7JF

name: Monifieth Skatepark
description: This is quite an odd park with a bit of a mish-mash of features, part street area with banks and stairs and part bowl with transition and coping. Note: This might be worth a look if you're in the area but it's not up to much compared to other larger skateparks in the area such as Carnoustie, Arbroath or Dudhope Skatepark in Dundee.
address: Marine Drive, Monifieth, Angus, Scotland, DD5 4NH

name: Tayport Skatepark
description: Brand new outdoor concrete park built in 2019. Street area with various ledges and quarterpipes, approx 1.5m deep bowl.
address: Top Park, Off Queen Street, Tayport, Fife, Scotland, DD6 9LR

name: Whitfield Skatepark
description: New concrete skatepark which is actually a large extension to some existing small pre-cast modular concrete quarterpipes. The park is a mixture of quarters with a rollover / funbox and pyramid / driveway.
address: Lothian Crescent, Dundee, Dundee City, Scotland, DD4 0XP

name: Finlathen Skatepark
description: This is a pretty unusual small concrete park built on a tiny budget. It consists of two back-to-back rectangular flat-banked bowls with a semi-circular platform at one end with a curvy rails going round it. There's also a small driveway / pyramid on the platform at one side with a small ledge on it.
address: Fontainbleau Drive, Dundee, Dundee City, Scotland, DD4 8ET

name: Dudhope Skatepark
description: Dudhope Skatepark was constructed in 2005 and opened to the public in February 2006. The park is built from concrete and is approximately 100 square metres in size. A small extension was added to the skatepark in 2014 which replaced the existing slabbed areas with proper concrete and filled in the big grassy area next to the bowl. This extension added some new small transitioned banks, a bank to ledge near the bowl and a long grind ledge.
address: Dudhope Park, Dundee, Tayside, Scotland, DD1 5RG

name: South Road Skatepark
description: Small park with nice little mini-ramp with spine into a flat street area with driveway, rail into a quarter and flat bank.
address: South Road Park, Dundee, Dundee City, Scotland, DD2 4SR

name: Newport Skatepark
description: Newport skatepark is an outdoor concrete park with a great mix of street obstacles and transition. There is a decent sized bowl which is approximately 7 foot in the deep end complete with pool coping and 5 foot in the square shallow end with metal coping. The rest of the area has a mix of street obstacles mixed in with an eclectic mix of transitions, banks and ledges. Great for beginners and experienced riders.
address: Next to Waterstone Crook Sports Centre, Kirk Road, Newport on Tay, Fife, Scotland, DD6 8HY

name: Coupar Angus Skatepark
description: Concrete skatepark featuring a bowl, ramp, grind bars and benches.
address: Meigle Road, Coupar Angus, Perth and Kinross, Scotland, PH13 9ES

name: Blairgowrie Skatepark
description: Small metal park with funbox and quarters.
address: Ferguson Park, Hatton Road, Rattray, Perth and Kinross, Scotland, PH10 7AR

name: Pitlochry Skatepark
description: Small outdoor concrete bowl with a few metal ledges / rails around it.
address: Recreation Ground, Ferry Road, Pitlochry, Perth & Kinross, Scotland, PH16 5DZ

name: Errol Skatepark
description: Outdoor concrete bowl with a flat bank leading to a street area with driveway and ledges. Surfaces may be a bit rough.
address: Errol Public Park, Errol, Perth & Kinross, Scotland, PH2 7SN

name: Aberfeldy Skatepark
description: Very small park with flat bank with grind bar, sketchy spine and fun box. Surface of the park is quite old and rough.
address: Victoria Park, Taybridge Terrace, Aberfeldy, Perth and Kinross, Scotland, PH15 2BS

name: Scone Skatepark
description: Approx 1.8m high metal miniramp.
address: Scone Recreation Park, Stormont Road, Scone, Perth & Kinross, Scotland, PH2 6RU

name: Perth Skatepark
description: Situated just outside the main town centre, Perth Skatepark at South Inch represents the start of Scotland's New Concrete.  Perth skatepark was the first big custom concrete skatepark build of the current crop of skateparks, built by Clachan in 2003 with designs done by the then Perth and Kinross Council Landscape architect, Clive Bowman.  Perth incorporate features to cater for all tastes of park skating with a big linked main reservoir area which includes a funbox, 10 foot quarter pipe, spine and Marseille teardrop.  It also houses a rectangular midi bowl, smaller beginner section and various banks, stairs and rails round the outside.
address: Lesser South Inch, Shore Road, Perth, Perth and Kinross, Scotland, PH2 8EB

name: Methven Skatepark
description: Very small park with a curved rail, flat bar, small rollover / bank, two-level manual pad with flat bar. Recommended to take a brush to sweep aways sticks and stones.
address: King George's Jubilee Park, Main Street, Methven, Perth and Kinross, Scotland, PH1 3ST

name: Crieff Skatepark
description: Small park with a bowl and four-sided funbox with a couple of flat bank hips.
address: School Bus Road, Broich Road, Crieff, Perth & Kinross, Scotland, PH7 3SG

name: Comrie Skatepark
description: Outdoor concrete park, bowled areas with spine leading into street area with banks, driveway ledges. Great little park out in the countryside!
address: Laggan Park, Crieff Road, Comrie, Perth & Kinross, Scotland, PH6 2EA

name: Cupar Skatepark
description: Outdoor concrete bowl with street obstacles on tarmac.
address: Duffus Park, Balgarvie Road, Cupar, Fife, Scotland, KY15 4AQ

name: Crail Skatepark
description: Small concrete modular skatepark. Quarterpipes, driveway, rails.
address: St Andrews road (A917), Crail, Anstruther, Fife, Scotland, KY10 3UP

name: Kinross Skatepark
description: Concrete bowl with large platforms which have various ledges around it.
address: Loch Leven Leisure Pool, Kinross, Perth & Kinross, Scotland, KY13 8SY

name: Auchterarder Skatepark
description: Interesting bowl setup with a deep-end with sloping escalator down to shallow end.
address: Western Road, Auchterarder, Perth & Kinross, Scotland, PH3 1JG

name: Dunblane Skatepark
description: It is very awkward to get to with a 15/20 min walk up a big hill into a massive park, the park has VERY dated concrete with cracks everywhere and coping out of shape from the ramps, it has a VERY steep bowl with aspects of Livingston original skatepark but to the scale of a childs play area it is small, there is a flatbar going along and down (requires gardening to skate it) and same goes for the ledges. The rollins are uneven and most of the time your better acid dropping or even olling into the rollin instead of rolling in.
address: Laighhills Public park, Dunblane, Stirlingshire, Scotland, FK15 0AQ

name: Stirling Skatepark
description: New park built in 2012. Nice layout and uses part of old park in new design.
address: King's Park, King's Park Road, Stirling, Stirlingshire, Scotland, FK8 2JS

name: Cowie Skatepark
description: Large bowl and street area, various transitions, different heights. Approximately 750m2 in size.
address: Berryhill park, Cowie, Stirlingshire, Scotland, FK7 7AH

name: Alloa Skatepark
description: Large park 600m2 with floodlights, a variety of street features and bowl, very popular since opening on 18th June 2016. Supported and developed by Clackmannashire Council Youth Services and local young people.
address: Bowmar Centre, Scott Crescent, Alloa, Clackmannanshire, Scotland, FK10 1BT

name: Sauchie (Fairfield) Skatepark
description: Outdoor concrete skatepark with a bowled mini ramp with spine / rollover into a quarter pipe. This leads into a funbox with various ledges then into a rounded lipped banked area.
address: Abbey Craig Road, Sauchie, Alloa, Clackmannanshire, Scotland, FK10 3DJ

name: Leven Skatepark
description: Street orientated skatepark construction in old paddling pool area. Also has separate concrete bowl area added a few years ago.
address: Promenade, Leven, Fife, Scotland, KY8 4PH

name: Glenrothes Skatepark
description: Outdoor concrete park, a lot of transition on offer but also some flat banks, rails, ledges.
address: Riverside Park, Leslie Road, Glenrothes, Fife, Scotland, KY7 5TD

name: Tarshall Skatepark
description: Concrete park built circa 2018 to replace an old metal ramp-based skatepark. Many features including a miniramp, spine, rails, humps and hubbas, Placed at the edge of Tanshall Park next to a MUGA.
address: Tanshall Park, Glenrothes, Fife, Scotland, KY6 2JJ

name: Kinglassie Skatepark
description: Outdoor concrete park with halfpipe with bowled end, hexagonal pyramid, flat banks and ledges.
address: Lochty Park, Burnside Road, Kinglassie, Fife, Scotland, KY5 0XN

name: Kirkcaldy (Bevy) Skatepark
description: Outdoor concrete park built in the early 2000's. More street focused than transition with various flat banks, pyramid / driveways, ledges.
address: Beveridge Park, Abbotshall Road, Kirkcaldy, Fife, Scotland, KY2 5LZ

name: Ballingry (Benarty) Skatepark
description: Outdoor concrete park with a large street section, a 6 stair with hand rail and Hubba ledges. It has a large triangle bank section that flows towards the halfpipe section of the park. This section has a large spine with varied sized quarter pipes . In the far corner of the skatepark there is a large bowl with a banked wall. Deep end of bowl is 9ft.
address: Flockhouse Avenue, Ballingry, Lochgelly, Perth & Kinross, Scotland, KY5 8EX

name: Lochgelly Skatepark
description: Outdoor concrete skatepark with a mix of transition and street features. Miniramp with spine section leading into banked area with rail. Low three step set with small hubba ledge. Jumpbox with flatbank landing.
address: Hall Street, Lochgelly, Fife, Scotland, KY5 9LS

name: Cowdenbeath Skatepark
description: Large outdoor concrete park, lots of transitions, large bowl with round pool at one end with a whole load of hips and corners. Various funbox / jumpbox features with more quarters, curving spine. There's a lot to ride here!
address: Central Park, Stenhouse Street, Cowdenbeath, Perth & Kinross, Scotland, KY4 9DG

name: Dunfermline Skatepark
description: The skatepark is around 15 years old (2018), it is a nice set up but starting to crack up and is needing a repair, it is made up of two twins and a roll in on one side, a box and a flat bank and another curved ramp, it also has a spine, a tiny stair set at the back and a few other rails. Very early stage plans are underway for creating a new skatepark else where elsewhere in Dunfermline, but no further details are known at this time (Nov 2018).
address: Saint Margarets Drive, Dunfermline, Fife, Scotland, KY12 7JA

name: Bruntisland Skatepark
description: Outdoor concrete park with various transitions, vert extension on the big quarter, driveway, jumpbox.
address: Lammerlaws Road, Burntisland, Fife, Scotland, KY3 9BS

name: Rosyth Skatepark
description: This is an outdoor concrete park originally built circa 2013 with a bowl / halfpipe leading into jumpbox and street area. In 2020 it was extended by Bendcrete Skateparks with the addition of a quarterpipe / hip behind the existing bowl, a manny pad flanked by a flat bar and hip and a ledge leading to a quarterpipe at the other end,
address: 1 Holborn Place, Rosyth, Dunfermline, Fife, Scotland, KY11 2LG

name: Dalgety Bay Skatepark
description: Small concrete park with a mix of street elements such as rails, ledges and flat banks as mini-ramp and quarterpipes.
address: Dalgety Bay Sports and Leisure Centre, Harbour Drive, Dalgety Bay, Fife, Scotland, KY11 9NA

name: Inverkeithing Skatepark
description: Concrete park, mini ramp leading in to an extended bowled out end. Mini ramp ends are banks leading to a tabletop banked section on one side with a pump track bit on the other side. These both lead to a larger transitioned quarter pipe which leads to another section with a ledge, mogul and smaller quarter pipe.
address: Ballast Bank Community Centre, Preston Crescent, Inverkeithing, Fife, Scotland, KY11 1DS

name: Falkirk Skatepark
description: This park has a massive long circle rail on flat ground about shin height, it has a HUGE concrete flatbank with a quarter (verging on vert), a huge stair set with a massive square ledge a funbox with ledges and a hip (bothsides) on the edge of the funbox and there is a long mini ramp too, lots of flat ground too.
address: Bellsmeadow Rd, Falkirk, Stirlingshire, Scotland, FK1 1SD

name: Arbonhill Skatepark
description: This skatepark has quite rough flat ground with various features: flatbank, steep funbox with ledge, quarter pipe, small fat circle rail, a small block ledge with rounded edge. There is also a halfpipe (which was built on a bit of a gradient so when you drop in from one side you gain more speed and are much slower on the return so a lot of leg work is involved!).
address: Moss Road, Abronhill, Cumbernauld, North Lanarkshire, Scotland, G67 3NZ

name: Kilsyth Skatepark
description: Small concrete bowl with driveway and rollover and bump (There looks to be quite a few stones around it as the surrounding area has not been landscape yet, so probably worth taking a brush with you to clean it out)
address: Rennie Road, Kilsyth, Glasgow, Glasgow City, Scotland, G65 9BA

name: Kirkintilloch Skatepark
description: This park is mainly a transition skaters heaven, big massive bowl, lots of quarters. There are some street aspects such as ledges at the top of flatbanks, a 2 stair stepup with a hubba ledge going down too. There is also a beginners section which has some very small quarters, a tight mini-ramp, a decent flat bank and also a circle rail with slanted edges.
address: Parliament Street, Glasgow, East Dunbartonshire, Scotland, G66 3AD

name: Lennox Skatepark
description: Outdoor concrete park, originally a park was built here in 2005 but a new park was built in 2017. Features a mix of transitions and street with quarterpipes, driveway, ledges etc.
address: Keystone Avenue, Milngavie, East Dunbartonshire, Scotland, G62 6JE

name: Unit23 Skatepark
description: Unit 23 skatepark is the largest indoor skatepark in the UK and has been open since 2002. There is over 56,000 sq-ft of space with ramps spread over 3 halls to suit everyone and every skill level including a massive replica of the legendary little devil bowl & a huge foam pit.
address: The Old Bond, 45 - 50 Castlegreen Street, Dumbarton, Strathclyde, Scotland, G82 1JD

name: Linwood Skatepark
description: There are actually two skateparks here, the original one is older and is a bit of a mish-mash of obstacles with stairs on roll-ins and generally badly laid features. It's fun to cruise around but not great for serious skating. The newer park is a bit worse for wear too unfortunately, there is a mini ramp with cracked concrete and sometimes melted objects on it, there is a funbox with a ledge with a flat bank when you come off the funbox. There is a flat ledge too and a circle railing leading from the old park to the new one but the surface is terrible.
address: Brediland Road, Linwood, Paisley, Glasgow, Strathclyde, Scotland, PA3 3RA

name: Renfrew Skatepark
description: Large park with a lot of varying features, bowls, spines, hips and a street section.
address: Paisley Road, Renfrew, Renfrewshire, Scotland, PA4 8JL

name: Knightswood Pump Track
description: Outdoor tarmac pump track next to the bigger Glasgow BMX centre. Located in a nice area with easy access by train and bus. Note that there can be lots of small stones filling in the beds around so bring a brush to give it a sweep clean before use.
address: Archer Hill Road, Knightswood, Glasgow, Glasgow City, Scotland, G13 3LS

name: Drumchapel Skatepark
description: It is a fun little park, lots of small transition everywhere with a small spine into a 5ft bowl which is quite large, there is also a street section too which can be a bit hit or miss. Note, sometimes it can be a great place for a session, often it can be quite empty of skaters but there is also the chance that it might be a bit overrun by local youth, most of which are alright but sometimes it can result in the park being a bit of a mess, glass all over the place. A fun wee park none the less but take care when visiting.
address: Southdeen Play Area, 76 Southdeen Avenue, Glasgow, Strathclyde, Scotland, G15 7RR

name: Largs Skatepark
description: Concrete skatepark featuring a combination of bowls, quarters, jump box, ledges, rails etc. Suitable for both experienced and beginner skaters.
address: Mackerston Place, Largs, North Ayrshire, Scotland, KA30 8BY

name: Battery Park Skatepark
description: Outdoor concrete skatepark with a bowl, quarterpipes and ledges.
address: Battery Park, Eldon Street, Greenock, Inverclyde, Scotland, PA16 7UA

name: Evolution Skatepark
description: Lots of transition, some steep and close to vert parts, it has alot of funboxes, rails and ledges scattered about the place, only downside to the funboxes is the ledges on them are very small and out of proportion. It has some fantastic flatbanks and hips, it's worth going to see it.
address: Saltcoats Road, Stevenston, Saltcoats, Ayrshire, Scotland, KA20 3JR

name: Shred Skatepark
description: The park has a rhythm jump, street and bowl section with quarter pipes 3, 5, 6, 7 and 8 foot in size. The bowl has a hipped spine, 5 foot quarter to wall and a 16 foot high vert wall, jump section with 15 foot wide jump box into a step up. Street section with small flat banks with a flat down rail, flat rail and a driveway with box.
address: 1 Boundary Road, Ayr, Ayrshire, Scotland, KA8 9SN

name: Ayr Skatepark
description: Outdoor pre-fab skate park that has been there for quite a long time. Mini ramp, quarter pipes rails and blocks, located in a slightly sketchy area (known as 'shitepark' by the locals!).
address: 2 Whitletts Road, Ayr, South Ayrshire, Scotland, KA8 0JB

name: Kennedy Skatepark
description: Legend has it that this skatepark is older than the castle ruins that it stands beside, all we know is that there's not much left of it apart from a funbox with stairset with rail and a small freestanding grind rail. This must be one of the best views / surroundings of any skatepark in Scotland, but definitely not one to visit unless you're into archaeology!
address: Kennedy Park, Castle Road, Dunure, Ayrshire, Scotland, KA7 4LW

name: Glenluce Skatepark
description: Outdoor concrete park with bowled miniramp area, taco, driveway, ledges, flatbar, quarterpipes.
address: 70 Main St, Glenluce, Newton Stewart, Dumfries & Galloway, Scotland, DG8 0PS

name: Kirkcudbright Skatepark
description: 25m skatepark with a mix of street features and quarter pipes. Intended to provide variety for both novices and experienced skaters. The skatepark is community owned and operated.
address: Gartshore Park, Castledykes Road, Kirkcudbright, Dumfries & Galloway, Scotland, DG6 4AW

name: Dumfries Skatepark
description: Outdoor concrete skatepark with miniramp / bowl area, street area with driveway / funbox, ledges, rails etc.
address: 47 Kingholm Road, Dumfries, Dumfries & Galloway, Scotland, DG1 4SR

name: Neilston Skatepark
description: Outdoor concrete park, three bowled areas with spine, hips and rollover.
address: Kingston Playing Fields, Neilston, Glasgow, East Renfrewshire, Scotland, G78 3DY

name: Barrhead Skatepark
description: Outdoor concrete park with in a v-shape arrangement. Wide hipped-quarterpipe which leads in two directions, the first into a jumpbox line to a quarterpipe, the second to a more street focused line with rails, ledges, manny pad and flat bank.
address: Cowan Park, Aurs Road, Glasgow, East Renfrewshire, Scotland, G78 2RN

name: Corkerhill Skatepark
description: Outdoor metal modular skatepark. Mini ramp, 2 Quarter pipes facing a flat pyramid/driveway.
address: Corkerhill Road, Cardonald, Glasgow, Glasgow City, Scotland, G52 1PZ

name: Riverside Transport Museum
description: The ‘Transport’ spot at the Riverside Museum in Glasgow came out of a conversation Glasgow Museums had in 2017 with Jamie Blair at Clan Skates. Given they present an exhibit that features Jamie and Colin Kennedy they couldn’t very well pass a ban at the front of their building when issues around skating arose, even less so because the ledges out the front were (rather poorly) designed with skating in mind. The resulting conflict of use at the museum's entrance led them to find a way to welcome skaters that didn’t clash with the general public (You CAN still skate the ledges, just do so when the museum is closed after 5pm). Following initial discussions Jamie approached Glasgow Urban Sports, a charity that’s been working longterm on developing new terrain in Glasgow, to help formulate some ideas for using the very limited budget available to build more skateable stuff in a less prominent part of the site. With the support of our GUS colleagues Neil Davidson and Angus McPhee and the enthusiastic input of Youngo and the crew at Concreate Skateparks, Raydale Dower and I used our experience as skaters and artists to develop a plan that might make a spot rather than a skatepark. The idea was to make it feel like a legit street spot despite featuring purpose built elements and we did this by trying to modify the museum's existing hard landscaping rather than imposing a ‘facility’ on the site. We wanted to match materials and make the space flow in a way that meant non-skaters might not even register the changes we were making. The result is a hybrid space for shared use; a mix of public thoroughfare, skate spot, hangout zone and even scenic barbecue location. We wanted it to be a complementary counterpoint to Kelvingrove and it's turned out to be a significant addition to the scene in Glasgow and a draw for visiting skaters too. All this was achieved in a matter of months on a sub £15k budget because we had a willing partner/landowner in Glasgow Museums, a committed and flexible contractor and an innovative yet frugal vision for the site. Hopefully it can act as an inspiration for other local authorities and statutory bodies as it proves you don’t need hundreds of thousands of pounds and years of toil to create something that skaters will enjoy.
address: The Riverside Museum of Transport and Travel, 100 Pointhouse Rd, Glasgow, Glasgow City, Scotland, G3 8RS

name: Kelvingrove Skatepark
description: Outdoor concrete park with a good mix of features, mellow bowls, quarters with spine, stairs and square flatbar down rails, ledges.
address: Kelvingrove Park, Kelvin walkway, Glasgow, Glasgow City, Scotland, G3 7SE

name: The Loading Bay
description: Glasgow’s newest indoor skatepark. Opening hours are 10am and 10pm 7 days a week. Excellent bowl and street areas. Cafe area with great food.
address: 100 Borron St, Glasgow, Glasgow City, Scotland, G4 9XE

name: FakieSB Store Skate Spot
description: FakieSB is a skateboard shop equipped with some ramps to test out your new board or sesh with your mates! With 2 quarters, bank and ledge it is the perfect training ground to nail those tricks you've been wanting to take out to the park or street.
address: 5 Osborne Street, Glasgow, Glasgow City, Scotland, G1 5QN

name: Rouken Glen Skatepark
description: This is a fibreglass skatepark, all ramps are prefabs. It has some larger boxes (knee height) and rails the same, a massive big flat bank, a funbox with a ledge and some cracking good hips as well with quarter pipes scattered about and a quarter to jump box too. (Vets surgery has a public carpark for use right beside the skatepark open 24/7)
address: Rouken Glen Park, Rouken Glen Road, Giffnock, East Renfrewshire, Scotland, G46 7UG

name: Queens Park Vert Ramp
description: Known locally as 'The Wrecks', this park has been there a LONG TIME, likely more than 20 years. It is a prefab fibre glass skatepark, most of the ramps are destroyed now, there are some rails, little spine, an old school giant kicker and of course the Iconic Vert ramp, only reason that Vert is still skateable is because people repair it themselves. The coping has detached from the actual ramp a few times but has been repaired, there isn't really anything else worth going for other than the vert if you're into that (Sadly, at the time of publishing Sept 2017, this is practically the only vert ramp in Scotland which is a sad state of affairs!).
address: Queens Park, 16A Queen's Drive, Glasgow, Strathclyde, Scotland, G42 8BS

name: Cathkin Braes Pumptrack
description: Whilst primarily built for bikes pump tracks are great for all types of wheeled activities, definitely good fun for pumping around and a pretty good workout too!
address: 231 Ardencraig Road, Glasgow, Glasgow City, Scotland, G45 0HR

name: Hairmyers Skatepark
description: Very basic modular metal skatepark. Quarterpipe, driveway with rails and flatbank.
address: Hairmyers, Mossneuk Road, East Kilbride, Glasgow, South Lanarkshire, Scotland, G75 8XA

name: East Kilbride Skatepark
description: This park is old but has lots of transition, a lot of quarters and a vert half pipe section, a 4 set of stairs, a small funbox and a small ledge. The surface is quite rough due to it being an old park.
address: Cornwall Street, East Kilbride, South Lanarkshire, Scotland, G74 1AF

name: Camlachie / Barrowfield Skatepark
description: Outdoor concrete park in a recently revamped urban community park. It's a reasonably small park with various small transitioned areas that are generally less than 1.4m in height, two rollover bumps and small quarterpipes at each end.
address: Barrowfield Park, Barrowfield Street, Glasgow, Glasgow City, Scotland, G40 3RP

name: Beardmore Skatepark
description: Very basic, lots of rails. One metal spine and one metal slight flatbank/kicker. Small area and not very good. Ground is acceptable. Big ledges right next to it along with a small 3 set. This park is quite old and may not be worth visiting unless you happen to be passing by!
address: Beardmore park, 384 Westmuir Street, Glasgow, Glasgow City, Scotland, G31 5DA

name: Blackhill Skatepark
description: This is an outdoor concrete park featuring some concrete hips and a kind of bowled flatbank area. NOTE: This park is in disrepair, construction quality is poor but it has also been set on fire several times.
address: Molendinar Park, Craighead Avenue (Off Royston Road), Blackhill, Glasgow, Lanarkshire, Scotland, G33 1LP

name: Cranhill Bowl
description: This is a pretty strange facility and included here more out of novelty value than of it being something worth visiting. The bowl is like a cereal bowl, it is a perfect circle and quite mellow. There are some other small obstacles there but are in various states of disrepair - not that there was much there to begin with anyway. This place is sometimes referred to as 'Cranhill Mini ramp' and their is indeed a halfpipe, however, this is a roll-in halfpipe on a hill! More like an American-style storm drain like in the videos. Note: definitely not worth travelling to visit but included here for the sheer novelty and weirdness factor.
address: Cranhill Park, Crowlin Crescent, Easterhouse, Glasgow, Strathclyde, Scotland, G33 3PG

name: Barrachnie Park Skatepark
description: Fibre glass prefab ramps most are rusted beyond repair, not recommended in its current condition. As of November 2020 there is some movement for new facilities to happen.
address: Mount Vernon Avenue, Glasgow, Strathclyde, Scotland, G69 7LS

name: Coatbridge Skatepark
description: Small concrete park with mini ramp, small 3ft quarter to a 5 ft quarter, thick round rail on flat, double-stair set with a sharp down ledge, a curved down-ledge and a small wallie bank separating the different heights in the park. Often very busy.
address: Westend Park Public Park, Glasgow, North Lanarkshire, Scotland, ML5 1ET

name: Airdrie Skatepark
description: Small concrete park, 6 foot concrete halfpipe with a flatbank running down off one side, wee funbox thing, 3/4 wee pool, 2 quarter pipes, wee minispine, wee slidebars; and up top end is a minibowl and halfpipe section with big set of stairs and an impossibly steep wee handrail down them.
address: Leisure Centre, Motherwell St, Rawyards, Airdrie, North Lanarkshire, Scotland, ML6 7HU

name: Blantyre Skatepark
description: Large scale park built in early 2000. Lots of transition at varying heights meaning loads of fun. Watch out for mental neds.
address: Glasgow Road, Blantyre, South Lanarkshire, Scotland, G72 0JF

name: Bellshill Skatepark
description: The park is on the smaller side with a couple of down-ledges and a rail which can be difficult to skate. However there is a nice flow to the park if carved. The open-ended 4-6ft bowl at the back, gives speed for the euro-gap at the front of the park. The entrance starts with two small drop-in ramps either side of a larger bank/drop-in. In the middle of the park is a small fun box opposite a slightly curved, 'wave-shaped' bank. The coping on the bowl is sunken into the ramp slightly which can be challenging.
address: 25 Park gate place, Bellshill, North Lanarkshire, Scotland, ML4 3HE

name: Radworx Indoor Skatepark
description: Radworx indoor skate park, more like a Skate Club for 8 year olds and up. Note: It is a small park with limited open times during winter only! Nov to Feb, usually open just on Saturday but check on Facebook 'Radworx action sports'. Ramps - Nice 4.5' high miniramp 20' wide. Wall ride and Q pipe with escalator to bowled corner. Flat bank with block at top. Other blocks, rails and kickers to move around. Be aware No Scooters or BMX allowed in park and can be difficult to find the first time, it is in the car park behind Sun Shack tanning shop round corner from Hamilton west train station. If never skateboarded and wanting to give it a go the Rad staff do free skateboard lessons for 8 years old and above.
address: Regen-FX Youth Trust, Summerlee House, Summerlee Road, Larkhall, South Lanarkshire, Scotland, ML3 9AY

name: North Motherwell Skatepark
description: Small outdoor concrete park with mini ramp section and small street section. Tight transitions but fun little park.
address: Magna Street, North Motherwell, South Lanarkshire, Scotland, ML1 3QZ

name: Motherwell Street Plaza
description: This is a pretty unusual skatepark that is shaped like a plaza but in a circle. At the top there is a massively long set of stairs taking you to the main centre of the park (stairs have a big handrail, very long). You can skate around the spiral going over some humps then to a small bank to bank section, then a small ledge then either a kicker or a flat bar to skate going round then once you are in the middle there is like a curved 2 tier ledge (highest height being knee height), then there is a flat bank and a set of stairs which give not much room for landing and little sharp banks around the outer circle containing the park.
address: Duchess Park, 117 Avon Street, Motherwell, North Lanarkshire, Scotland, ML1 3AL

name: Wishaw Skatepark
description: Small outdoor concrete park with quarterpipes, funbox and grind ledges. Although built quite recently it's considered to be poorly designed and built skatepark largely due to quite tight transitions for the height. A lack of maintenance and vandalism has impacted some of the surface of the park. A decent little park if you're local but perhaps not worth going out of your way to visit.
address: Belhaven Park, Glenpark Street, Wishaw, Glasgow, North Lanarkshire, Scotland, ML2 7RE

name: Overtown Skatepark
description: No current information on this park.
address: Overtown Public Park, Main Street, Overtown, North Lanarkshire, Scotland, ML2 0QF

name: Carluke Skatepark
description: Built as part of a 3 satellite park scheme for south lanarkshire. Giant flat bank, half crescent bowl, quarter pipes, 2x small funboxes one with a ledge other with hips, small ledge on flat. Carpark onsite too.
address: Glenafeoch Road, Carluke, South Lanarkshire, Scotland, ML8 4NY

name: Whitburn Skatepark
description: Outdoor concrete park with small bowl leading into a street area with driveway with ledge and rail and quarterpipe.
address: Baillie St, Whitburn, Bathgate, West Lothian, Scotland, EH47 0ER

name: Blackburn Skatepark
description: The park consists of a closed bowl, a street course and a beginner’s area, all of which can be used separately or as one on quieter days. The bowl has a straight section or ‘mini-ramp’ with an escalating pocket, a large steep flat bank extension and a clam shell extension. The back of the step bank extension becomes a platform for the bowled out micro quarter pipe that gives speed for the street course level change. The beginners section has a half penny bank and a small, dipped roll-in bowl with curved spine that leads to a kicker wedge with hubba that links back to the main street course.
address: Murrayfield Park, Ash Grove, Blackburn, West Lothian, Scotland, EH47 7LJ

name: West Calder Skatepark
description: Outdoor concrete skatepark with a bowl, banks, rollers / wave, grind ledges / rails, quarterpipe and hips. Built by Bendcrete in 2019.
address: 163 Harburn Drive, West Calder, Lothian, Scotland, EH55 8AW

name: Livingston Skatepark
description: Livingston Skatepark opened in 1981, at a time when most commercial skateparks were closing and was one of the most important facilities in Britain during a critical period in the development of skateboarding. It is an example of a free, unsupervised facility which achieved international status. The skatepark was extended during the 1990s with the addition of some smaller bowls. A further extension was added in 2013 adding a fullpipe, pools, square bowl and a new smaller street / beginners area.
address: Almondside, Livingston, West Lothian, Scotland, EH54 6QU

name: Uphall Skatepark
description: Uphall is about a 7 minute drive from Livi or a 20 minute drive from Edinburgh. This is a nice wee park that makes good use of the available space for the park. Its on the main street so you will not really be able to miss it if you drive down the main street. Overall this is a nice wee park and well worth a skate. So get on down dodge the bikers and skate tough.
address: Goschen Place, Uphall, Broxburn, Edinburgh, West Lothian, Scotland, EH52 5JJ

name: Sighthill Skatepark
description: Outdoor metal ramp-based skatepark. 6ft mini ramp, driveway with grind box, jump box, flat bank, rails and grind boxes. Possibly not in the best condition now as it's at least 15 years old.
address: Sighthill Public Park, 319 Broomhouse Road, Edinburgh, Lothian, Scotland, EH11 3UY

name: Saughton Skatepark
description: Well thought out and designed park, amazing pool coping bowl, over-vert cradle, street course and loads quarters.
address: Balgreen Rd, Edinburgh, Lothian, Scotland, EH11 3AX

name: Drylaw Skatepark
description: No current information about this park
address: 102 Easter Drylaw Drive, Edinburgh, Lothian, Scotland, EH4 2RT

name: Skelf Pump Track
description: Pumptracks are mainly built for bikes, however you can ride them on anything with wheels so well worth checking out if you're in the area, definitely good fun for pumping around and a pretty good workout too!
address: Bowmont Place, Edinburgh, East Lothian, Scotland, EH8 9RY

name: Portoello Skatepark
description: 390 sq metre skatepark designed to be young people friendly but also provides plenty of opportunity for progression. It can often be very busy but built to be able to have 3 different sessions at once on the middle section, 4ft mini ramp and street section. The park features a variety of ledges, quarterpipes, spine, flatbanks and rails, and also a nice red-painted kerb and manual pad.
address: Treverlen Park, Duddingston Road, Portobello, Edinburgh, Lothian, Scotland, EH15 1NF

name: Penicuik Skatepark
description: Outdoor concrete park with a good mixture of transition and street features. 6ft miniramp, funbox, flat-bank to wallride, quarterpipes, driveways. Designed by Dave Sowerby.
address: 56 Jackson Street, Penicuik, Midlothian, Scotland, EH26 9BJ

name: Bonnyrigg Skatepark
description: Outdoor concrete park with street section including funbox, ledges rails and a stair set (4 or 5) and a quarter pipe at either end. Also has a bowl, the shallow end is about 5ft and the deep end is about 7ft.
address: King George V Park, Bonnyrigg, Edinburgh, Midlothian, Scotland, EH19 2AD

name: Haddington Skatepark
description: Concrete skatepark with bowled minicamp section with rollover flowing into long street section with rails, ledges and banks.
address: Recreation Ground, Victoria Terrace, Whittingehame Drive, Haddington, East Lothian, Scotland, EH4 14AQ

name: Athelstaneford Skatepark
description: The park consists of a closed bowl, a street course and a beginner’s area, all of which can be used separately or as one on quieter days. The bowl has a straight section or ‘mini-ramp’ with an escalating pocket, a large steep flat bank extension and a clam shell extension. The back of the step bank extension becomes a platform for the bowled out micro quarter pipe that gives speed for the street course level change. The beginners section has a half penny bank and a small, dipped roll-in bowl with curved spine that leads to a kicker wedge with hubba that links back to the main street course.
address: 21 B1343, Athelstaneford, East Lothian, Scotland, EH39 5BF

name: Gullane Skatepark
description: No current information
address: Memorial Recreation Park, Near Hamilton Crescent, Gullane, Lothian, Scotland, EH31 2

name: North Berwick Skatepark
description: Outdoor modular skatepark. 5ft Mini ramp, concrete street area with quarterpipe, driveway, ledge, rail and flatbank.
address: Recreation Park, Dunbar Road, North Berwick, East Lothian, Scotland, EH39 4DQ

name: Dunbar Mini Ramp
description: Small outdoor modular concrete park, mini ramp, jump box and quarterpipe.
address: Pine Street, Dunbar, East Lothian, Scotland, EH42 1PN

name: Galashiels Skatepark
description: Park consists of 1 x 3 1/2 foot mini-ramp, not very wide and panels need work. A concrete construction with plastic / wood combo ramps. 1 x Funbox, 3 mellow flatbanks with poor lips between concrete and ramp. Grindbox runs down one side of this box. 1 x manual / grindbox, around 5 meters long and about half a meter high. 1 x Flatbank, reasonable incline - runs on to the funbox. 1 x Quarter pipe. This completes the run from flatbank to grindbox. Poor lip between concrete and ramp. Around 4-5 feet high. The park is situated next to a kids park, has no bins, is fairly basic and not worth a trip to unless you're in the area.
address: Abbots Place, Galashiels, Scottish Borders, Scotland, TD1 3BU

name: Kelso Skatepark
description: Outdoor concrete skatepark. Bowl with various corners / hips. Street area, flatbank, driveway, ledges, rails, quarters.
address: Dryhouse Lane, 51 Shedden Park Road, Kelso, Borders, Scotland, TD5 7BW
